caption_text: (1990) the lumped-species reaction scheme, which is depicted in Fig. 1, has been developed. It accounts for all species that are relevant for kinetic, fluid dynamic, and economic aspects of the M1 O process. Since the dehydration of methanol is very rapid and almost at equilibrium even at tempera- tures lower than 400 C, methanol (MeOH) and dimcthylethcr (DME) form lump A (oxygenates).
raw_window: (1990) the lumped-species reaction scheme, which is depicted in Fig. 1, has been developed.
It accounts for all species that are relevant for kinetic, fluid dynamic, and economic aspects of the M1 O process.
Since the dehydration of methanol is very rapid and almost at equilibrium even at tempera- tures lower than 400 C, methanol (MeOH) and dimcthylethcr (DME) form lump A (oxygenates).

caption_text: CFB reactor model In order to predict the product composition of the MTO process a comprehensive CFB reactor model has been developed, the basic structure of which can be seen from Fig. 2. A more detailed description of the CFB reactor model, its mathema- tical background, and the experimental determina- tion of model parameters with respect to fluid mechanics and interfacial mass transfer have been outlined elsewhere (Schoenfelder et a!., 1994). Therefore, only a brief description will be given.
raw_window: CFB reactor model In order to predict the product composition of the MTO process a comprehensive CFB reactor model has been developed, the basic structure of which can be seen from Fig. 2.

A more detailed description of the CFB reactor model, its mathema- tical background, and the experimental determina- tion of model parameters with respect to fluid mechanics and interfacial mass transfer have been outlined elsewhere (Schoenfelder et a!., 1994).
Therefore, only a brief description will be given.

caption_text: CFB reactor experiments A scheme of the MTO plant is given in Fig. 4. Methanol is fed to the reactor from a vessel with excess pressure. The pressure is exerted by nit- rogen.
raw_window: CFB reactor experiments A scheme of the MTO plant is given in Fig. 4.
Methanol is fed to the reactor from a vessel with excess pressure.
The pressure is exerted by nit- rogen.

caption_text: The cyclone dip legs are connected to a low velocity buffer fluidized bed (diameter 0.1 m, height 0.3 m), which is fluidized by nitrogen using a gas chromatography Fig. 3. Schematic of the Berty reactor system. Performance of a circulating fluidized-bed reactor 5381 Fig. 4.
raw_window: The cyclone dip legs are connected to a low velocity buffer fluidized bed (diameter 0.1 m, height 0.3 m), which is fluidized by nitrogen using a gas chromatography Fig. 3.
Schematic of the Berty reactor system.
Performance of a circulating fluidized-bed reactor 5381 Fig. 4.

caption_text: As can be seen from Fig. 4, the pressure in the buffer fluidized bed and regenerator is controlled. The pressure of the buffer and regenerator should lie between the pressure of the syphon, where the pressure is highest, and the pressure in the cyclones. Thus, the pressure differences arc compensated by equal solids hold-ups in the downcomer above the buffer and the syphon, respectively.
raw_window: As can be seen from Fig. 4, the pressure in the buffer fluidized bed and regenerator is controlled.
The pressure of the buffer and regenerator should lie between the pressure of the syphon, where the pressure is highest, and the pressure in the cyclones.
Thus, the pressure differences arc compensated by equal solids hold-ups in the downcomer above the buffer and the syphon, respectively.

caption_text: The temperature dependence of the kinetic constants was tested for Arrhenius law, and the results are shown in Fig. 5. There is a good agreement with the exponential temperature dependence. Note the negative slope of the temperature dependence for the kinetic parameter k4.
raw_window: The temperature dependence of the kinetic constants was tested for Arrhenius law, and the results are shown in Fig. 5.

caption_text: These reactions include not only forward reactions, as depicted in Fig. 1, but also reverse reactions [e.g. paraffins demethanization (Mihail et a!., (1983a)]. It should be considered that the proposed lumped-species MTO reaction scheme is a formal description which is sufficient for modeling the product distribution.

paraffins demethanization (Mihail et a!., (1983a)].
It should be considered that the proposed lumped-species MTO reaction scheme is a formal description which is sufficient for modeling the product distribution.

caption_text: In Fig. 7 a typical example of predicted and measured concentration profiles of the most impor- tant MTO species is given for a temperature of 40ffl~ The measurements plotted have to be understood as the average value of a number (3 5) of separate measurements, the experimental error of which is included into the figures. The concen- trations of the by-products methane, ethane and butane are not plotted, because the measured and predicted values are low. As can be seen from Fig. 7, at the operating conditions chosen, less than 80% of the methanol is converted into the desired olefin species.
raw_window: In Fig. 7 a typical example of predicted and measured concentration profiles of the most impor- tant MTO species is given for a temperature of 40ffl~ The measurements plotted have to be understood as the average value of a number (3 5) of separate measurements, the experimental error of which is included into the figures.
The concen- trations of the by-products methane, ethane and butane are not plotted, because the measured and predicted values are low.
As can be seen from Fig. 7, at the operating conditions chosen, less than 80% of the methanol is converted into the desired olefin species.

caption_text: The experiments given in Fig. 8 have been carried out at the higher temperature of 450 C. The outlet methanol / DME conversion is higher than in the former example (400 C). Obviously, there is a quite reasonable prediction of the overall reactor behavior for these operating parameters.
raw_window: The experiments given in Fig. 8 have been carried out at the higher temperature of 450 C.
The outlet methanol / DME conversion is higher than in the former example (400 C).
Obviously, there is a quite reasonable prediction of the overall reactor behavior for these operating parameters.

caption_text: In Fig. 9 a similar plot as in the previous figures is depicted for a reactor temperature of 500 C and a solids hold-up of 0.6 kg. At these operating conditions only small methanol OME concentra- tions (CMCOH< 1.5 e.%) are found at the riser exit. Again, this overalL behavior corresponds well with the model calculations.

caption_text: In Fig. 10 the measured outlet methanol + DME conversions at three different reactor temperatures are plotted versus whsv~1. Additionally, the calcu- lated conversion, which was predicted by the CFB reactor model, is compared with the experimental data. Since methanol is assumed to be in equilib- rium with DME, the methanol I- DME conversion is defined as the sum of the carbon fractions of all species except methanol and dirnetbyletber.

caption_text: In Fig. 11 the concentrations of the most impor- tant MTO product species are plotted versus whsvt at a temperature of 400 C. As a measure of concentration the product carbon fraction is used. This term denotes the fraction of carbon of a certain species i and the total amount of carbon that originates from all species except methanol / DME.

caption_text: In Fig. 12 the measured and predicted product distribution for a temperature of 450 C is depicted. Compared with the temperature of 400 C, the ethene concentration is reduced by a factor of two, whereas the concentration of propene is higher. The selectivity of the process with respect to olefins is increased by the elevation of the temperature, because the product carbon fraction of the by- products is reduced to values of 3 c.
raw_window: In Fig. 12 the measured and predicted product distribution for a temperature of 450 C is depicted.
Compared with the temperature of 400 C, the ethene concentration is reduced by a factor of two, whereas the concentration of propene is higher.
The selectivity of the process with respect to olefins is increased by the elevation of the temperature, because the product carbon fraction of the by- products is reduced to values of 3 c.

caption_text: At a temperature of 500 C the behavior of the CFB reactor with respect to the product distribu- tion shows an interesting phenomenon: as can be seen from Fig. 13, the product carbon fractions of propene and butene exhibit extrema at a medium residence time. The concentration of the by- products is very low at this high temperature (<3 c.%), resulting in very high olefin yields (>97 c.%) due to the almost complete methanol conversion at these operating conditions. The CFB reactor model is able to properly predict the behavior of the system at a temperature of 500 C.
raw_window: At a temperature of 500 C the behavior of the CFB reactor with respect to the product distribu- tion shows an interesting phenomenon: as can be seen from Fig. 13, the product carbon fractions of propene and butene exhibit extrema at a medium residence time.

The concentration of the by- products is very low at this high temperature (<3 c.%), resulting in very high olefin yields (>97 c.%) due to the almost complete methanol conversion at these operating conditions.
The CFB reactor model is able to properly predict the behavior of the system at a temperature of 500 C.

caption_text: This can also be seen in Fig. 13, where only the predicted ethene concentration shows a notable deviation from the experimental data. 5. SUMMARY The present study has shown that the combina- tion of the H-ZSM 5 zeolite catalyst (VAW AG) and the CFB reactor is an excellent system for the selective conversion of methanol to low molecular olefins.
raw_window: This can also be seen in Fig. 13, where only the predicted ethene concentration shows a notable deviation from the experimental data.

SUMMARY The present study has shown that the combina- tion of the H-ZSM 5 zeolite catalyst (VAW AG) and the CFB reactor is an excellent system for the selective conversion of methanol to low molecular olefins.
